message: Yes
http://www.akshell.com - would love your feedback, we've got some exciting stuff in the works with jsFiddle as well btw.
I liked the look of it, I just immediately thought I probably wouldn't use it unless I could install in-place compilers and be able to write in CoffeeScript / Stylus etc.
This is based on ACE, right?
I believe there is a CommonJS CoffeeScript module which you can use, so we do support any languages that compile to JavaScript.
Excellent, let's talk on http://groups.google.com/group/akshell
The editor that is, the server is custom built Apache MPM like setup on top of V8.
Cool.
Being able to write in the language of choice and have it save out as JavaScript is pretty vital to me nowadays.
Cool. I'm getting ready to launch another language JS11 which would be great to get syntax highlighting for as well.
For my own work I use an interlacer that places the original source code into the exported JS file, so that I can alter the original in a special editor.
One thing that's missing is syntax highlighting of CoffeeScript and easier setup, but we are working on that.
There is more to it that just highlighting of course, since ideally we would like to show the stack traces from the original language, rather than JavaScript.
But that could be implemented later.
Posted a message there, thanks for the link.
I still remember Akshell before the Cappucino-based editor :)
@myfreeweb good stuff, we're hoping to keep up the rate of progress, so imagine what it will look like in one year ;)
Looks pretty cool.  Unfortunately, I'm no longer capable of using a code editor that doesn't have vim bindings.  I guess tmux+vim+bash will continue to be my IDE for now.
@oleg, speaking about the good stuff, here's what I made on akshell: http://names.akshell.com
@jayferd we can probably work something out - could you please post this as a suggestion on http://feedback.akshell.com ?
@myfreeweb very nice, I remember that - are there any other projects you're thinking of starting?
Cool to see people using Cappuccino! Did you build the UI with Atlas/Interface Builder, or did you just do it all in code?
We used Atlas.
This looks pretty neat.
@oleg, nope
Please allow for underscores in user names....
